APS Stechkin
The Stechkin APS is a Russian selective fire machine pistol, bearing the name of its designer Igor Stechkin. Originally chambered for 7.62x25mm Tokarev, the pistol was changed to use 9x18mm as it became clear that this cartridge was set to become the new service ammunition for handguns in the Soviet Army. In 1951, the Stechkin was introduced into the Soviet military arsenal, replacing the aging TT-33.

Beretta 92F
Beretta 92F
Beretta 92F
The Beretta is perhaps best known as the standard pistol of the US Military that replaced the legendary M1911. Known for being accurate, durable and reliable, it's been adopted by several countries and has been setting the standards for military, police and tactical pistols for over a quarter century.

Browning Hi-Power
Browning Hi-Power
A single-action, semi-automatic pistol based on the ideas of American firearms inventor John Browning. Browning died in 1926 before finishing a production version, but FN arms designer Dieudonne Saive completed the pistol's development. The Hi-Power pistol was noted for its 13-round magazine, twice that of contemporary designs such as the Luger or Mauser 1910. Despite its venerable age, the Browning HP enjoys popularity around the world.

Colt M1911
Colt M1911
Colt M1911
Colt M1911
Designed by John Browning, the M1911 is an extremely reliable and robust pistol that remained the standard-issue side arm of the US military from 1911 to 1985. To this day, it remains very popular for military, police and civilian use around the world.

Colt M1911 "Aries"
Designed by John Browning, the M1911 is an extremely reliable and robust pistol that remained the standard-issue side arm of the US military from 1911 to 1985. To this day, it remains very popular for military, police and civilian use around the world. The "Aries" has been modified with a feather-trigger for faster firing, lightweight parts for easier concealed carry and a tritium ironsight.

Designed by John Browning, the M1911 is an extremely reliable and robust pistol that remained the standard-issue side arm of the US military from 1911 to 1985. To this day, it remains very popular for military, police and civilian use around the world. The "Orion" has been modified with a a tritium ironsight and a heavier barrel and stock, greatly increasing its accuracy.

CZ-75
Developed by the Koucky brothers, this semi-automatic pistol was intended for the export market. The CZ-75 accumulated the best features from many preceding designs with the resulting pistol being aesthetically attractive, comfortable, accurate and reliable in operation.

FNP-45
A recoil-operated, polymer-framed pistol that provides good accuracy, outstanding reliability and versatility in a weapon that is comfortable to handle. Created as a homage to John Browning of the M1911 in .45 ACP, it offers an impressive amount of ambidextrous features, even when compared to modern pistols.

FNX-45
FNX-45
Improving on the FNP-45, the FNX-45 is the latest in technological advancements in handgun engineering, offering .45 ACP performance and a host of unique features that no other handgun can match. The cold hammer-forged stainless steel barrel has a threaded muzzle for the integrated suppressor and the stainless steel slide comes with high-profile combat night sights for easier target acquisition.

Glock 19
Reliability, durability and simplicity have made the Glock 19 one of the most widely used sidearms in law enforcement. Due to its reduced dimensions when compared to the Glock 17, it is ideal for use as a backup weapon or for concealed carry purposes.

Reliability, durability and simplicity have made the Glock 19 one of the most widely used sidearms in law enforcement. Gsh-18
Gsh-18
In the early 2000s, the Russian military sought a new light, effective and easily concealable sidearm to replace the Makarov. Designed by Gryazev and Shipunow, the outcome was the Gsh-18; a recoil-operated, striker-fired, locked breech pistol and, at the time of production, the lightest pistol in the world. It was immediately adopted by all branches of the Russian military.

HS2000
The choice sidearm of the Croatian military and law enforcement, the HS2000 is a semi-automatic, striker-fired pistol known for its excellent ergonomics and outstanding safety features. Today, the HS family of pistols, based on the HS2000, has evolved into more than 50 different models.

Makarov PM
Makarov PM
This Soviet legacy is one of the best compact self-defence handguns available. Small, highly reliable, easy to use and easy to maintain, the Pistol Makarova was selected because of its simplicity, easy manufacturing, accuracy and reasonable stopping power. Unfortunately though, it loses out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight, magazine size and general performance.

Makarov PM "Ceremonial"
This Soviet legacy is one of the best compact self-defence handguns available. Small, highly reliable, easy to use and easy to maintain, the Pistol Makarova was selected because of its simplicity, easy manufacturing, accuracy and reasonable stopping power. Unfortunately though, it loses out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight, magazine size and general performance. The "Ceremonial" was originally given to Alexander Degtyarev as a reward for "Successful execution of highly dangerous state orders, as well as valor and courage shown in the line of duty". Other than the addition of tritium iron sights, the pistol's differences are of little note.

Makarov PMM
A redesign of the legendary Makarov, the PMM uses a 25% increase in gas pressure to significantly increase muzzle velocity and features a larger 12-round magazine. Though, even with these changes slightly bridging the gap between itself and modern pistols, it still loses out in terms of weight and general performance.

MP-412 Rex
A Russian .357 double-action revolver most notable for its unique break-action chamber and automatic ejector. Though it was designed for export (REvolver for eXport), it never was put into full production due to lack of a market and restrictive gun import laws in the United States.

MP-443 Grach
One of the standard military-issued sidearms in Russia, the MP-443 Grach is a double-action, short-recoil, semi-automatic pistol known for its reliability and versatility in the field. It is widely recognized for its smooth trigger pull and simplified design making it easy to disassemble and maintain.

OTs-33 Pernach
Developed to replace the Stechkin APS in special paramilitary units, the OTs-33 is a blowback-operated pistol capable of automatic and semi-automatic fire. The Pernach was specifically tasked with resolving the difficulty of controlling recoil in full-auto mode present in the Stechkin APS pistol and simplifying it for combat deployment. It is cheaper to manufacture, more controllable and boasts improved recoil.

PB
PB
The PB (Pistolet Besshumnyj or Silent Pistol) was developed in 1967 for Spetsnaz units of the Soviet Army and KGB operatives. The pistol is based on a modified Makarov PM and features a unique integrated two-part suppressor that reduces bullet velocity to below subsonic levels.

TT-33

Armsel Protecta
Armsel Protecta
Armsel Protecta
The uniquely designed Armsel Protecta (also known as the Striker) is a rotating cylinder-fed 12-gauge shotgun developed for riot control and infantry combat and was intended to provide extreme firepower for militarized units. Antiquated now by the Russian Saiga-12 and the American AA-12, the Protecta was a revolutionary weapon at the time benefiting from a large magazine and a high effective rate of fire, though its bulkiness, considerable weight and long reload time are the trade-offs for these advantages.

SVT-40
SVT-40
A semi-automatic rifle that saw widespread service during and after World War II. Originally intended to be the Soviet Army's new service rifle, its production was disrupted by the German invasion in 1941, resulting in a change back to the Mosin–Nagant for the duration of World War II. After the war, the Soviet Union adopted new rifles, such as the SKS and AK-47.

Desert Eagle
The IMI Desert Eagle is a semi-automatic handgun notable for chambering the largest centrefire cartridge of any magazine fed, self-loading pistol and also being the heaviest and blockiest gun of its type. You can use it to bludgeon your enemies to death because of its blockiness and weight. Rumour is that there's a stalker with a crowbar wandering around the Zone with a rechambered version of this gun.
Desert Eagle "Steppe Eagle"
This weapon was brought to the Zone by a stalker named Logan Williams. Disguised as a TIME photographer he managed to single-handedly enter the centre of Pripyat. His current whereabouts are unknown, but he is rumoured to work as an information broker specializing in all matters related to the Zone.
 

VSSK Vykhlop
A integrally suppressed Russian bullpup, straight-pull bolt-action sniper rifle chambered for subsonic rounds. Intended for special stealth operations, typical targets for the VKS are combatants in heavy body armor or located behind cover.

Walther WA 2000
The Walther WA 2000 is a semi-automatic bullpup sniper rifle produced by the Carl Walther GmbH Sportwaffen company from 1982 until 1988. It was produced in three different calibers. Production of the rifle was limited and was shortly stopped because it was too expensive to achieve widespread sales and not robust enough for military use as a sniper rifle. Only 176 were built, making it one of the rarest and most sought out production firearms ever made.

GP-25 Grenade Launcher
A single shot, front loaded, rifled under-barrel grenade launcher for assault rifles made in Warsaw Pact countries. Designed to greatly expand fire-power of a basic infantry squad. The firing mechanism is self-cocking, with a manual safety catch and automatic shot prevention if incorrectly installed onto a rifle.

M79
A shoulder-fired, break-action, single shot grenade launcher first appearing during the Vietnam War. Recoil is kept low by means of a 'High-Low Propulsion System' where propellant is stored in a high-pressure chamber, allowing much larger projectiles to be launched without the heavy equipment usually needed. When the propellant is ignited, the gases are bled out through vents at reduced pressure to a much larger, low-pressure chamber to push the projectile forward. The high-low system allows the weight of the weapon and its ammunition to be reduced significantly.
